prediction.line: MENTOR: Eschewing material well-being, he despises the company of lesser people and those undistinguished by good birth. He likewise avoids contact with boorish and boorishly self-assured people (phanestrōitai). He inclines towards genuine intimacy with people endowed with fine qualities, he loves associating with people with noble temperaments and avoids the company of people who show a disreputable character. For in their circle and friendship he feels unable to spare the attentions necessary to further and improve himself. For surely that benefit others offer he does not refuse—to make a short reference, the traditional prescriptions emphasizing thoughtfulness towards others—but in addition he attempts to improve himself individually. It falls to his lot to be in the pocket of a sophist, he avoids contact with them; instead he utilizes them by keeping them
prediction.sentence:
For Hector certainly seemed, among the fighters on the side of Achilles, to be greater than Ajax in fighting; and they were debating concerning arms; and Achilles prevailed, whence it was that so great lamentation rose for him among all the Danaans; and so were the Trojans eager to pursue the Greeks; and [Hector] seized on one of the largest and most unwieldy to drag (it being) the tomb of Ilus, son of Assaracus; but his effort was being hindered by Cebriones so that he (sc. Hector) might not give it to the enemy, who were marching behind, and might not thus disgrace the Trojans, nor seem to depart from the opinion of Calchas, owing to (the latter's) talk, for when the Greece that lay in the four divisions happened to be held in council, the opinion was that he had been killed (διαχρῆσθαι). But as he was dragging it (sc. the tomb-stone), up came Odysseus, and laid it upon the point of his spear, and was carried in triumph towards the [tent] of Achilles; and he slew Pedaeus, his attendant, who had just come back, and there was brought in to be lamented, and he was lamenting him as he lay in the ashes with sad cries and blackened clothes, and (also) that (sc. Odysseus) showed himself the most able of the Greeks; and the epithet Rombophoros, which is addressed to the name of Odysseus” — that epithet stands against the name of Menelaus in the Column IIII., — “and which means, “Rubber of Troy,” has evidently been given as opposition to the epithet Lokroi of Odysseus, “the Disturber of Trojans,” Anth. Pal. vii. 447, if indeed he is not the proper oppositor of the Lokri of Diomedes, the “Disturber of Greeks.” I owe this supposition to the kindness of Prof. Hermann Groliers, to whom I am indebted in other ways for well-meant discussion of this passage (ὁ Αας could be read for ὁ Μαστιγο- Führungs-fähigkeit. [It is about the relation of MENELAUS and MENELAIOI that a similar question of Führungs-fähigkeit arose in the IG discussion of gB.]


ADDENDA ET CORRIGENDA:

No. 890, 7. 25. iwta for Ticoria.

Page 344, note 1. Diet. Hell. gr. et rom. x. 177, xvpiffov πέρατα is exemplified, not quoted, in Hell. ad loc. The variant xwπffov, unless adopted in conj. with the preceding πέρατα, seems superfluous: it is superfluous everywhere in Greek before words beginning with π, save of course in relative and demonstrative pronouns; and επαλιν εὑπέδησεν before ἐ-πεδήνατο taken together are so well-known from Alcaeus that, I suppose, there rose expectations only of somewhat repetitive phrases beginning with περόν and ending with ium, as on the preceding page in
prediction.region: The Trojan Female Costume, which consists of Barbarian and Aehenian Materials, is the Rescue followed by the Mistaken Debate about Helen's deception, and the Plot of the Mysfetes. For Patroclus, about to die in a combat against the shining Achilles, seemed to surpass Achilles in his body’s lively energy and in armor; and in the debate about weapons Achilles took possession of all four, whence the fugitive Patroclus somehow avoided the judgment, wherefore the Achaians delivered the weapons to the Trojans, so that when they began the battle again, Achilles held due possession of the armor, which is the reason for him not having to contend with Menelaus again. When having strangled, as if hanging up dead, the most excellent warrior, named Lycomedes, Achilles both knocked down this Lycomedes, and threw him inside a certain tent, where the judgment to take place, when the Trojan and Achaian armies met, where the funeral of Penthesilea would be concluded, and where, too, the fierce Amazon is seen burning the dead. Indeed, around the thighs and around the woman-killer’s neck they placed both the trophies and the well-known inscription, which we now see in museums. But in the copies, given to the public by the rhapsodists, we find that Achilles is the killer of Lycomedes; however, it still need to search, going through the philosopher in his lectures, how and why this imitator changed it, through the dissimilarity of its opposing position with Lycomedes. At any case, the winner of Alëathanos seems dead through the just judgment, and in the discourses Achilles seems to be similar to the dead.

ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

JOHNA. OEDIPUS. AIA. OEDIPUS. "For I am, and not so long ago, the child of Labdacus [15]" whom certain enemies were stealing away. And now, when I look at your face on statuesque ships, I see that Agamemnon, shepherd of the army, has come to the same crime, he whom I have seen giving a last and woeful account of his booty, hunting down the signs of his enemy's hands, so that you might see whether they were inside or outside, with hands that are free from gore; certainly, dogs in the Laconian Shores represent Oedipus's fault as much as an unyielding ass's [16] footprint. [17] And to end my life among strangers, in no way does this gate against which You fear to come, run counter to your fate. For if what you say is true, it is now that I hear him, with a cry for help, though I know not how it is, in absolute confusion. [18] But he seems like a wounded-marked man, striking with his fist at a clustered wall of bronze metal [19]—such a man as is to be seen in Tirisan—and now, because of his wrath, he will fly up and down, hanging from the threshold. One needs no longer approach this door, for my feature seems to be enough to set a herald running off to find Alcmene. [20]

[15] During the Lion's/Dioscouri's chorus, Jocasta has sung to Oedipus, προτρέϒην τίν’... Λάβδακες, "to whom did your parents beget you, O child Labdacus". At Agamemnon's arrival Jocasta's original emotion is confirmed: Agamemnon, whose father Atreus was human as well as divine, ended up as a murderer. Both Atreus (in Aeschylus) and Agamemnon (in Euripides’ play) installed their sons in power, when they themselves had reached old age. Choral songs inform the characters that the main action will be wonderful—Aias says this about the present play and at Agamemnon’s entrance Tiresias seems confident that the subject of his song would hold the audience spellbound. [16] At this point in the play Choruses again sing a kind of refrain. The chorus sings of Teiresias’ prophecy: Theban boys—kings and aristocrats—will be killed by their fathers. Lyceum, the site where many young people began their education, is used in Aeschylus as the symbol of a short life. The children were at Lycia or in Lycian Highlands because the people had just suffered a deadly plague: the chorus of Lycian women sings in Euripides' Bacchae that they "have lost twice seven children". The song of the chorus emphasizes the central theme of this play, violated Oedipus’ oath, which he swore after admitting he had killed the previous king Laius and received the power via his marriage with Jocasta. Yet, in the original perception of the play the only murdered man was Laius, whom Oedipus found next to a blooming 5 taxus tree at Thebes. We do not know from Sophocles' play himself who this Laius really was but Jocasta hints that she and Oedipus had killed a robber, in Episode 3 of Aeschylus’ Seven against Thebes—a robber who had killed their former king. It is only from this statement and from the title of the play that Laius becomes an older Machanidas, whose raiment has been stained by human blood: Laius dies by a sword, his blood at the bottom of his clothes distracts the officials because it cannot dry there but rather flows through his whole body. [17] Agamemnon starts like many Attic tragedians’ characters: he begins with a description of Laius’ head, which is supposed to remind the audience of the death of Laius after an autopsy. Laius’ death by Oedipus in short: he beheaded Laius–who represented the central theme of the play-by his own blade, his assassin's sword. A phantasmagorical parabasis [19] enhances the drama of Oedipus’ recitation: Obviously crying over his tortures Agamemnon is hurting himself with his own fists and he is using his blood-stained hands to describe the dreadful action. Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

prediction.region:
JOHNA. OEDIPUS. AIA. OEDIPUS. "For I am, and not so long ago, the child of Labdacus [15]" whom certain enemies were stealing away. And now, when I look at your face on statuesque ships, I see that Agamemnon, shepherd of the army, has come to the same crime, he whom I have seen giving a last and woeful account of his booty, hunting down the signs of his enemy's hands, so that you might see whether they were inside or outside, with hands that are free from gore; certainly, dogs in the Laconian Shores represent Oedipus's fault as much as an unyielding ass's [16] footprint. [17] And to end my life among strangers, in no way does this gate against which You fear to come, run counter to your fate. For if what you say is true, it is now that I hear him, with a cry for help, though I know not how it is, in absolute confusion. [18] But he seems like a wounded-marked man, striking with his fist at a clustered wall of bronze metal [19]—such a man as is to be seen in Tirisan—and now, because of his wrath, he will fly up and down, hanging from the threshold. One needs no longer approach this door, for my feature seems to be enough to set a herald running off to find Alcmene. [20]

[15] During the Lion's/Dioscouri's chorus, Jocasta has sung to Oedipus, προτρέϒην τίν’... Λάβδακες, "to whom did your parents beget you, O child Labdacus". At Agamemnon's arrival Jocasta's original emotion is confirmed: Agamemnon, whose father Atreus was human as well as divine, ended up as a murderer. Both Atreus (in Aeschylus) and Agamemnon (in Euripides’ play) installed their sons in power, when they themselves had reached old age. Choral songs inform the characters that the main action will be wonderful—Aias says this about the present play and at Agamemnon’s entrance Tiresias seems confident that the subject of his song would hold the audience spellbound. [16] At this point in the play Choruses again sing a kind of refrain. The chorus sings of Teiresias’ prophecy: Theban boys—kings and aristocrats—will be killed by their fathers. Lyceum, the site where many young people began their education, is used in Aeschylus as the symbol of a short life. The children were at Lycia or in Lycian Highlands because the people had just suffered a deadly plague: the chorus of Lycian women sings in Euripides' Bacchae that they "have lost twice seven children". The song of the chorus emphasizes the central theme of this play, violated Oedipus’ oath, which he swore after admitting he had killed the previous king Laius and received the power via his marriage with Jocasta. Yet, in the original perception of the play the only murdered man was Laius, whom Oedipus found next to a blooming 5 taxus tree at Thebes. We do not know from Sophocles' play himself who this Laius really was but Jocasta hints that she and Oedipus had killed a robber, in Episode 3 of Aeschylus’ Seven against Thebes—a robber who had killed their former king. It is only from this statement and from the title of the play that Laius becomes an older Machanidas, whose raiment has been stained by human blood: Laius dies by a sword, his blood at the bottom of his clothes distracts the officials because it cannot dry there but rather flows through his whole body. [17] Agamemnon starts like many Attic tragedians’ characters: he begins with a description of Laius’ head, which is supposed to remind the audience of the death of Laius after an autopsy. Laius’ death by Oedipus in short: he beheaded Laius–who represented the central theme of the play-by his own blade, his assassin's sword. A phantasmagorical parabasis [19] enhances the drama of Oedipus’ recitation: Obviously crying over his tortures Agamemnon is hurting himself with his own fists and he is using his blood-stained hands to describe the dreadful action. Jocasta recognizes that Oedipus’ violation of his own oath has been completed and she asks Tiresias

"dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

groundtruth.region: ΑΘΗΝΑ. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.
prediction.prompt:
Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary and consists of the primary text only, in ancient Greek. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.line:
φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ τὰ περὶ γᾶς.



The automated transcription has introduced a mistake in the sequences σίγα and θρόνβα (stigme and thróphos), which have been mistranscribed συγα and θρόννα. This mistake changes the meaning of what was said: the fly was not snatched by a gull but by an owl.
prediction.sentence: Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κοντὴν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ἐγχώραφον σῆμα κατευθύς φροντίζω φλέγματι, ἄθροισμα μήτρας ἀρετῆς ὡς περαῖ, κώδῥῶ μαντεῖαν τύχης τότ’ ὄχημ’ ὡς βοηθήμ’ ἐμοὶ τοῦτον ὅλου γ
prediction.region:
JOHNA. OEDIPUS. AIA. OEDIPUS. "For I am, and not so long ago, the child of Labdacus [15]" whom certain enemies were stealing away. And now, when I look at your face on statuesque ships, I see that Agamemnon, shepherd of the army, has come to the same crime, he whom I have seen giving a last and woeful account of his booty, hunting down the signs of his enemy's hands, so that you might see whether they were inside or outside, with hands that are free from gore; certainly, dogs in the Laconian Shores represent Oedipus's fault as much as an unyielding ass's [16] footprint. [17] And to end my life among strangers, in no way does this gate against which You fear to come, run counter to your fate. For if what you say is true, it is now that I hear him, with a cry for help, though I know not how it is, in absolute confusion. [18] But he seems like a wounded-marked man, striking with his fist at a clustered wall of bronze metal [19]—such a man as is to be seen in Tirisan—and now, because of his wrath, he will fly up and down, hanging from the threshold. One needs no longer approach this door, for my feature seems to be enough to set a herald running off to find Alcmene. [20]

[15] During the Lion's/Dioscouri's chorus, Jocasta has sung to Oedipus, προτρέϒην τίν’... Λάβδακες, "to whom did your parents beget you, O child Labdacus". At Agamemnon's arrival Jocasta's original emotion is confirmed: Agamemnon, whose father Atreus was human as well as divine, ended up as a murderer. Both Atreus (in Aeschylus) and Agamemnon (in Euripides’ play) installed their sons in power, when they themselves had reached old age. Choral songs inform the characters that the main action will be wonderful—Aias says this about the present play and at Agamemnon’s entrance Tiresias seems confident that the subject of his song would hold the audience spellbound. [16] At this point in the play Choruses again sing a kind of refrain. The chorus sings of Teiresias’ prophecy: Theban boys—kings and aristocrats—will be killed by their fathers. Lyceum, the site where many young people began their education, is used in Aeschylus as the symbol of a short life. The children were at Lycia or in Lycian Highlands because the people had just suffered a deadly plague: the chorus of Lycian women sings in Euripides' Bacchae that they "have lost twice seven children". The song of the chorus emphasizes the central theme of this play, violated Oedipus’ oath, which he swore after admitting he had killed the previous king Laius and received the power via his marriage with Jocasta. Yet, in the original perception of the play the only murdered man was Laius, whom Oedipus found next to a blooming 5 taxus tree at Thebes. We do not know from Sophocles' play himself who this Laius really was but Jocasta hints that she and Oedipus had killed a robber, in Episode 3 of Aeschylus’ Seven against Thebes—a robber who had killed their former king. It is only from this statement and from the title of the play that Laius becomes an older Machanidas, whose raiment has been stained by human blood: Laius dies by a sword, his blood at the bottom of his clothes distracts the officials because it cannot dry there but rather flows through his whole body. [17] Agamemnon starts like many Attic tragedians’ characters: he begins with a description of Laius’ head, which is supposed to remind the audience of the death of Laius after an autopsy. Laius’ death by Oedipus in short: he beheaded Laius–who represented the central theme of the play-by his own blade, his assassin's sword. A phantasmagorical parabasis [19] enhances the drama of Oedipus’ recitation: Obviously crying over his tortures Agamemnon is hurting himself with his own fists and he is using his blood-stained hands to describe the dreadful action. Jocasta recognizes that Oedipus’ violation of his own oath has been completed and she asks Tiresias

"dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.
groundtruth.sentence: ΑΙΑΣ.
groundtruth.region: ΑΘΗΝΑ. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.
prediction.prompt:
Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary and consists of the primary text only, in ancient Greek. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
ΑΙΑΣ.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.line:
1. ΠΛΗΡΩΜΗΣ ΧΕΡΤΣΩΜΕΝΟΣ ΣΤ. ΑΝΤΧΟΦΟΙ.
2. Επιτηρείται από τους Αθηναίους. Πρόκειται ARISTOPHANES.
ARISTOPHANES. AIR-RISTHFA-NES. E-THSAI.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
2. Α
prediction.sentence: ΜΟΝΟΝ ΝΕΙΝ.—ΥΣΑΙΣ ΥΠΑΤΗΡ.
prediction.region:
JOHNA. OEDIPUS. AIA. OEDIPUS. "For I am, and not so long ago, the child of Labdacus [15]" whom certain enemies were stealing away. And now, when I look at your face on statuesque ships, I see that Agamemnon, shepherd of the army, has come to the same crime, he whom I have seen giving a last and woeful account of his booty, hunting down the signs of his enemy's hands, so that you might see whether they were inside or outside, with hands that are free from gore; certainly, dogs in the Laconian Shores represent Oedipus's fault as much as an unyielding ass's [16] footprint. [17] And to end my life among strangers, in no way does this gate against which You fear to come, run counter to your fate. For if what you say is true, it is now that I hear him, with a cry for help, though I know not how it is, in absolute confusion. [18] But he seems like a wounded-marked man, striking with his fist at a clustered wall of bronze metal [19]—such a man as is to be seen in Tirisan—and now, because of his wrath, he will fly up and down, hanging from the threshold. One needs no longer approach this door, for my feature seems to be enough to set a herald running off to find Alcmene. [20]

[15] During the Lion's/Dioscouri's chorus, Jocasta has sung to Oedipus, προτρέϒην τίν’... Λάβδακες, "to whom did your parents beget you, O child Labdacus". At Agamemnon's arrival Jocasta's original emotion is confirmed: Agamemnon, whose father Atreus was human as well as divine, ended up as a murderer. Both Atreus (in Aeschylus) and Agamemnon (in Euripides’ play) installed their sons in power, when they themselves had reached old age. Choral songs inform the characters that the main action will be wonderful—Aias says this about the present play and at Agamemnon’s entrance Tiresias seems confident that the subject of his song would hold the audience spellbound. [16] At this point in the play Choruses again sing a kind of refrain. The chorus sings of Teiresias’ prophecy: Theban boys—kings and aristocrats—will be killed by their fathers. Lyceum, the site where many young people began their education, is used in Aeschylus as the symbol of a short life. The children were at Lycia or in Lycian Highlands because the people had just suffered a deadly plague: the chorus of Lycian women sings in Euripides' Bacchae that they "have lost twice seven children". The song of the chorus emphasizes the central theme of this play, violated Oedipus’ oath, which he swore after admitting he had killed the previous king Laius and received the power via his marriage with Jocasta. Yet, in the original perception of the play the only murdered man was Laius, whom Oedipus found next to a blooming 5 taxus tree at Thebes. We do not know from Sophocles' play himself who this Laius really was but Jocasta hints that she and Oedipus had killed a robber, in Episode 3 of Aeschylus’ Seven against Thebes—a robber who had killed their former king. It is only from this statement and from the title of the play that Laius becomes an older Machanidas, whose raiment has been stained by human blood: Laius dies by a sword, his blood at the bottom of his clothes distracts the officials because it cannot dry there but rather flows through his whole body. [17] Agamemnon starts like many Attic tragedians’ characters: he begins with a description of Laius’ head, which is supposed to remind the audience of the death of Laius after an autopsy. Laius’ death by Oedipus in short: he beheaded Laius–who represented the central theme of the play-by his own blade, his assassin's sword. A phantasmagorical parabasis [19] enhances the drama of Oedipus’ recitation: Obviously crying over his tortures Agamemnon is hurting himself with his own fists and he is using his blood-stained hands to describe the dreadful action. Jocasta recognizes that Oedipus’ violation of his own oath has been completed and she asks Tiresias

prediction.region:
Pletho


Hushing the dogs at night from his shady

kiosk,

playing songs celebrating the Trojans’ wives . . . 204

But the Muse grieves to watch the ravished

Laodes

escaped alone through the gates of Hellas. Tales

of lovely Helen are over, the brass-man Hermes

rolling out of sight like a tarnished wheel. . . .

205

Fear did not pierce His heart with love for her.

As I believe, since he is the immortal Mind,

who possesses

the beautiful robe of blue and Its beauteous horses.

In this place already there assembled mortal

people,

blameless Trojans, who dwelled at Cotytto’s groves,

then also the Achaeans who arrived after them

210

and the herdsman who had the wisdom of portent

from the cattle of Lesbos.

Joyous and fearless they lived in a cave,

deprived of clothes,

215

and they feasted on abundance of fruit.

Truly their supernatural wisdom did render

the νοητὰοἱκαιρὸπαὶίθεαand their speech.

A great chieftain, nobly born,

220

a lawgiver, the worthy Minos, arose

to summon the children of those who dwelled

in luxuriousness, as well as to conquer

civilized Crete dwelling on the citadel.

He dedicated the exalted and holy lawcraft 225

where Cretans soon with pious black stone

build a temple honoring numerous seals.

Bacchus, lord of Ascania, rewards the Hellenes

with that cleansing water, where the noble

230

Minos appeared. And he detected the deadly reptiles

and the serpent which wicked Actaeon gazes upon,

when Actaeon his bow was not bending,

hoping to kill two fawns on the mountains

waiting to play with each other, rather he was gawking 235

at the god asleep nearby. Near to him Smertês

saw Medousa, his wife born of sea

who was pregnant with the multiheaded Gorgoneion.

He wanted her in plain daylight to become his own,

but she instructed him to cut off her

innocent head. “I will carry it,” he told her, 240

“until I look at it in daylight.” And she said no,

“Oh, monster, you’ll see it here in the dark!”

And she hid the child in the folds of her body.

Bitter, hard-hearted mother, her monstrous infant

crawling,

she found an untarnished jar, squeezed

the child in it; next she sealed it with pitch.

And Sphinês, eldest and immortal of the Gorgoni,

weeping,

carried it from Sicily, until she reached the lush plains 245

of the Bistonian river Euphrates; there she poured out

the black wine. The statue grew with the daughter of Asopos

and Cheirôn practiced his art in Achernar.

Tantalós who was degenerate before his father,

desiring excessively to have gold, suffered

from the grievous stone. He had poverty, and hunger

for food,

inserted upright into the hot ashes; Sisyphos

he watched, yet scarcely does the man approach 250

and gently that desperate one begged of

him “O wretched Sisyphos, stretched out right

on your rock, our suffering is the same.

If you can tell me of any way I will repay you

properly,

you’ll hear what you ask for and stand stronger.”


255

So promise. Sisyphos, kindly to the orphan, replies,

“Son of Aiakos, distracted man! Cease,

for you’re talking in vain, your noble tongue

without philosophy. It does not cross Your mind,

260

you, who are dying. And if I, who am suffering too,

I still have not perished, my friend; we share

something similar. Thus is He also accustomed

to use friends in the nights lightly. You have

shared the divine bed more than twice. You depend

on your

And she hid the child in the folds of her body.

crawling,

she found an untarnished jar, squeezed

the child in it; next she sealed it with pitch.

weeping,

carried it from Sicily, until she reached the lush plains 245

of the Bistonian river Euphrates; there she poured out

the black wine. The statue grew with the daughter of Asopos

and Cheirôn practiced his art in Achernar.

desiring excessively to have gold, suffered

from the grievous stone. He had poverty, and hunger

for food,

inserted upright into the hot ashes; Sisyphos

he watched, yet scarcely does the man approach 250

and gently that desperate one begged of

him “O wretched Sisyphos, stretched out right

on your rock, our suffering is the same.

If you can tell me of any way I will repay you

properly,

you’ll hear what you ask for and stand stronger.”


255

“Son of Aiakos, distracted man! Cease,

Bartleby.com has also done some of this work for Aristotle's "Ethics", "Rhetoric", and "Poetics", among others.
prediction.sentence:
Therefore, speaking against the teachings of the natural philosophers in such a way as not to use eis Theous or to introduce loftiness as an addition to the creation; neither do thou take a position speaking more regarding anyone except Deity and service to His God-Given Will; nor do thou bring in to thy mind an image more than the power of thy hand about what good fortune of a long life shall be preserved.
Noteworthy is the pointed omission of Basil’s reference to the sages at the beginning of ch 4 (scriptum iniuria principibus), an attack on his own instructor, Maximus the Confessor. Rodion Kratsouni (talk) 19:04, 18 September 2011 (UTC)

Hello! Please try to examine the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT" and fix the crowding problem. Note that the apostrophe in the 6th verse reads with the accent on the preceding vowel. The text I am working with was written with two spaces before each period, thus the left margin varies throughout the work. Getting the text into one column with the apostrophe appearing at the other margin is crucial. — Preceding unsigned comment added by DrAg10 (talk • contribs) 14:28, 20 September 2011 (UTC)

...στεφανὰς τὰς ὀνομασίας το

Ἐγὼ μὲν οὐδέν’ οἶδ’· ἐποικτείρω δέ νιν δύστηνον ἔμπας, καίπερ ὄντα δυςμενῆ, ὁθούνεκ’ ἄτῃ ξυγκατέζευκται κακῇ, οὐδὲν τὸ τούτου μᾶλλον ἢ τοὐμὸν σκοπῶν. ὁρῶ γὰρ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ὄντας ἄλλο πλὴν εἴδωλ’, ὅσοιπερ ζῶμεν, ἢ κούφην σκιάν. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Τοιαῦτα τοίνυν εἰςορῶν, ὑπέρκοπον μηδέν ποτ’ εἴπῃς αὐτὸς εἰς θεοὺς ἔπος, μηδ’ ὄγκον ἄρῃς μηδέν’, εἴ τινος πλέον ἢ χειρὶ βρίθεις ἢ μακροῦ πλούτου βάθει. ὡς ἡμέρα κλίνει τε κἀνάγει πάλιν ἅπαντα τἀνθρώπεια· τοὺς δὲ σώφρονας θεοὶ φιλοῦσι καὶ στυγοῦσι τοὺς κακούς.
prediction.prompt:
Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary and consists of the primary text only, in ancient Greek. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
ὡς ἡμέρα κλίνει TE κἀνάγει πάλιν ἅπαντα τἀνθρώπεια· τοὺς dd σώφρονας θεοὶ φιλοῦσι καὶ στυγοῦσι τοὺς κακούς.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.line:
θεοὶ φιλοῦσι καὶ στυγοῦσι τοὺς κακούς.

The verb θύω in Attic is a simple verb, not a compound as commonly believed. It is derived from an ancient inchoative *ti- 'wet, stain, anoint' whose present active is τει-. Spond.

The daughter word is ἱάω:

This verb derives from an Indo-European inchoative nondistinctive *s-(w)hi- 'flow, run', the well attested forms being *sēnu- 'run', *srou- 'stain

playing songs celebrating the Trojans’ wives . . . 204

Laodes

of lovely Helen are over, the brass-man Hermes

rolling out of sight like a tarnished wheel. . . .

205

then also the Achaeans who arrived after them

210

and the herdsman who had the wisdom of portent

from the cattle of Lesbos.

Joyous and fearless they lived in a cave,

deprived of clothes,

215

where Cretans soon with pious black stone

build a temple honoring numerous seals.

Bacchus, lord of Ascania, rewards the Hellenes

with that cleansing water, where the noble

230

Minos appeared. And he detected the deadly reptiles

and the serpent which wicked Actaeon gazes upon,

when Actaeon his bow was not bending,

hoping to kill two fawns on the mountains

waiting to play with each other, rather he was gawking 235

at the god asleep nearby. Near to him Smertês

saw Medousa, his wife born of sea

who was pregnant with the multiheaded Gorgoneion.

He wanted her in plain daylight to become his own,

but she instructed him to cut off her

innocent head. “I will carry it,” he told her, 240

“until I look at it in daylight.” And she said no,

“Oh, monster, you’ll see it here in the dark!”

And she hid the child in the folds of her body.

Bitter, hard-hearted mother, her monstrous infant

crawling,

she found an untarnished jar, squeezed

the child in it; next she sealed it with pitch.

And Sphinês, eldest and immortal of the Gorgoni,

weeping,

carried it from Sicily, until she reached the lush plains 245

of the Bistonian river Euphrates; there she poured out

the black wine. The statue grew with the daughter of Asopos

and Cheirôn practiced his art in Achernar.

Tantalós who was degenerate before his father,

desiring excessively to have gold, suffered

from the grievous stone. He had poverty, and hunger

for food,

inserted upright into the hot ashes; Sisyphos

he watched, yet scarcely does the man approach 250

and gently that desperate one begged of

him “O wretched Sisyphos, stretched out right

on your rock, our suffering is the same.

If you can tell me of any way I will repay you

properly,

you’ll hear what you ask for and stand stronger.”

to use friends in the nights lightly. You have

shared the divine bed more than twice. You depend

Ὁρᾷς, Ὀδυσσεῦ, τὴν θεῶν ἰσχὺν, ὅση ; τούτου τίς ἄν σοι τἀνδρὸς ἢ προνούστερος, ἢ δρᾷν ἀμείνων εὑρέθη τὰ καίρια ; ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ἐγὼ μὲν οὐδέν’ οἶδ’· ἐποικτείρω δέ νιν δύστηνον ἔμπας, καίπερ ὄντα δυςμενῆ, ὁθούνεκ’ ἄτῃ ξυγκατέζευκται κακῇ, οὐδὲν τὸ τούτου μᾶλλον ἢ τοὐμὸν σκοπῶν. ὁρῶ γὰρ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ὄντας ἄλλο πλὴν εἴδωλ’, ὅσοιπερ ζῶμεν, ἢ κούφην σκιάν. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Τοιαῦτα τοίνυν εἰςορῶν, ὑπέρκοπον μηδέν ποτ’ εἴπῃς αὐτὸς εἰς θεοὺς ἔπος, μηδ’ ὄγκον ἄρῃς μηδέν’, εἴ τινος πλέον ἢ χειρὶ βρίθεις ἢ μακροῦ πλούτου βάθει. ὡς ἡμέρα κλίνει τε κἀνάγει πάλιν ἅπαντα τἀνθρώπεια· τοὺς δὲ σώφρονας θεοὶ φιλοῦσι καὶ στυγοῦσι τοὺς κακούς.

prediction.region:
Pletho


Hushing the dogs at night from his shady

kiosk,

playing songs celebrating the Trojans’ wives . . . 204

But the Muse grieves to watch the ravished

Laodes

escaped alone through the gates of Hellas. Tales

of lovely Helen are over, the brass-man Hermes

rolling out of sight like a tarnished wheel. . . .

205

Fear did not pierce His heart with love for her.

As I believe, since he is the immortal Mind,

who possesses

the beautiful robe of blue and Its beauteous horses.

In this place already there assembled mortal

people,

blameless Trojans, who dwelled at Cotytto’s groves,

then also the Achaeans who arrived after them

210

and the herdsman who had the wisdom of portent

from the cattle of Lesbos.

Joyous and fearless they lived in a cave,

deprived of clothes,

215

and they feasted on abundance of fruit.

Truly their supernatural wisdom did render

the νοητὰοἱκαιρὸπαὶίθεαand their speech.

A great chieftain, nobly born,

220

a lawgiver, the worthy Minos, arose

to summon the children of those who dwelled

in luxuriousness, as well as to conquer

civilized Crete dwelling on the citadel.

He dedicated the exalted and holy lawcraft 225

where Cretans soon with pious black stone

build a temple honoring numerous seals.

Bacchus, lord of Ascania, rewards the Hellenes

with that cleansing water, where the noble

230

Minos appeared. And he detected the deadly reptiles

and the serpent which wicked Actaeon gazes upon,

when Actaeon his bow was not bending,

hoping to kill two fawns on the mountains

waiting to play with each other, rather he was gawking 235

at the god asleep nearby. Near to him Smertês

saw Medousa, his wife born of sea

who was pregnant with the multiheaded Gorgoneion.

He wanted her in plain daylight to become his own,

but she instructed him to cut off her

innocent head. “I will carry it,” he told her, 240

“until I look at it in daylight.” And she said no,

“Oh, monster, you’ll see it here in the dark!”

And she hid the child in the folds of her body.

Bitter, hard-hearted mother, her monstrous infant

crawling,

she found an untarnished jar, squeezed

the child in it; next she sealed it with pitch.

And Sphinês, eldest and immortal of the Gorgoni,

weeping,

carried it from Sicily, until she reached the lush plains 245

of the Bistonian river Euphrates; there she poured out

the black wine. The statue grew with the daughter of Asopos

and Cheirôn practiced his art in Achernar.

Tantalós who was degenerate before his father,

desiring excessively to have gold, suffered

from the grievous stone. He had poverty, and hunger

for food,

inserted upright into the hot ashes; Sisyphos

he watched, yet scarcely does the man approach 250

and gently that desperate one begged of

him “O wretched Sisyphos, stretched out right

on your rock, our suffering is the same.

If you can tell me of any way I will repay you

properly,

you’ll hear what you ask for and stand stronger.”


255

So promise. Sisyphos, kindly to the orphan, replies,

“Son of Aiakos, distracted man! Cease,

for you’re talking in vain, your noble tongue

without philosophy. It does not cross Your mind,

260

you, who are dying. And if I, who am suffering too,

I still have not perished, my friend; we share

something similar. Thus is He also accustomed

to use friends in the nights lightly. You have

shared the divine bed more than twice. You depend

on your

The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary and consists of the primary text only, in ancient Greek. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

AOHNA.

prediction.sentence:
κἀγὼ 700, ὃς δὲ τέως ἔθηλυθέντα βαφῇ ψηλῇ σίδηρος οὕτως ἐθηλύνθην στόμα ἐν πολέμοις, παρ’ ἐχθροῖς, παῖδα τ’ ὀρφανὸν παππίῳ, ἐν δ’ Ἄργει κατέχων ἀστιβῆ κίχω, κρύψω τόδ’ ἔγχος τούτους ὕμνους, ἔχθιστον βελῶν, γαίας ὀρύξας ἔνθα μή τις ὄψεται.

280
A few lines earlier in the same fragmentary text (fr. 700 Wright), the poet begs his Muse (Polumētis) to sing more of Polyneices's band of warriors. The poet asks his Muse to tell again about felling Deicoon's rapacious dogs, about baring the chest of melodious Maeonis to fighting, about plying his deadly spear on the soil of Eleusis.

instances where Ti is in agreement with one (or both) of the other two transmitted texts. One can think of a number of plausible explanations for this phenomenon,21 and we cannot establish that Ti is an improved version of at least one of the transmitted texts a priori. It is likely, though, that in certain cases Ti, which at one point was the preferred reading in antiquity, constitutes a further step in the ’Stissagio’ process, improvement of the transmitted texts.22 Often preference given to a certain line of transmission survives a change of hand in the transmission, e.g., when Scholia (scholion) come from different recensions.23 The emergence of a further step in the transmission after retouching of both transmitted texts is rarer, but it does occur, and it is likely that such examples will be obvious to anyone consulted for a revision.24

Plan of the book


The text printed in this volume is (almost) always, apart from very few exceptions, the new text set at the head of this introduction: Mark Paris 70 London, BM 47563. It is supplemented by the (also new) text of Parthenius Epigram 6, which is measured and transcribed by Adams 2004: 171. The readings of Diogenes Laertius and Aulus Gellius, labeled throughout as T and Tv, are (largely) presenting alternatives to those of Paris, T(e) and κκκ (cf. pauca supplementa and aHe s.v. κκκ), the choice here being informed by a “best guess” approach. Contrary to the vast majority of the new material contained in this volume, their readings are obviously not in need of reconstruction.

The text printed in this volume is (almost) always, apart from very few exceptions, the new text set at the head of this introduction: Mark Paris 70 London, BM 47563. It is supplemented by the (also new) text of Parthenius Epigram 6, which is measured and transcribed by Adams 2004: 171. The readings of Diogenes Laertius and Aulus Gellius, labeled throughout as T and Tv, are (largely) presenting alternatives to those of Paris, T(e) and κκκ (cf. pauca supplementa and aHe s.v. κκκ), the choice here being informed by a “best guess” approach. Contrary to the vast majority of the new material contained in this volume, their readings are obviously not in need of reconstruction.

The koine text is supplemented by the hypothesis of Guy Laron, Le

prediction.prompt:
Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary and consists of the primary text only, in ancient Greek. The text to correct appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
γαίας ὀρύξας ἔνθα μή τις ὄψεται.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.line:
καὶ γαίης ὄρυξας μή τις ὄψεται.


In cases where the OCR scanning software read punctuation incorrectly, please insert the correct Greek punctuation. Note that in Greek texts, if a period falls at the end of an incomplete line in OCR text, the period will be placed inside the line.


Thank you, Alpamayo 10:14, 9 September 2011 (UTC)

I restored some passages (in TEXT TO CORRECT and/or CORRECTED TEXT) that I Ceteridus (talk) had reintroduced from the original. There are mistakes in the original that explain the corresponding
prediction.sentence:
κἀγὼ 700, ὃς δὲ τέως ἔθηλυθέντα βαφῇ ψηλῇ σίδηρος οὕτως ἐθηλύνθην στόμα ἐν πολέμοις, παρ’ ἐχθροῖς, παῖδα τ’ ὀρφανὸν παππίῳ, ἐν δ’ Ἄργει κατέχων ἀστιβῆ κίχω, κρύψω τόδ’ ἔγχος τούτους ὕμνους, ἔχθιστον βελῶν, γαίας ὀρύξας ἔνθα μή τις ὄψεται.

280
A few lines earlier in the same fragmentary text (fr. 700 Wright), the poet begs his Muse (Polumētis) to sing more of Polyneices's band of warriors. The poet asks his Muse to tell again about felling Deicoon's rapacious dogs, about baring the chest of melodious Maeonis to fighting, about plying his deadly spear on the soil of Eleusis.
prediction.region:
Lto; “Pindar, Olympian 9.38”


Βακχεῖα δ’ ὕφασμα γένει δεῖ τετυγμένον τρέφειν ἀγήρων τε θηρῶν ᾧγελός” φάος οὐδέν, ἡ μὲν κατ’ ἀφαίρεσιν πρὸς ῥύθμον ἰῆλθε, τὸ δ’ οὔ. γάϊ πωμέν, ἀλλ’ ἀναίρε̣ται κἀμοὶ λέγοντι ὧν λαμβάνων βουλόμενον· εἰς δὲ θηρᾶν μᾶλλον ἐξεθανόμενον ἄρα γε μένων ἡγεμόατε, εὖ τοῦδὲ σοὶ παρίσταται.


CHROMEY’S TEXT: 35vv2–3 (Lto; vv2–3, Tr; vv2–3 Pl)

τὴν μὲν φαμὲν Ta κόσμῳ wsTe ’κεῖνα αὑτοὺς μὲν ἔχειν καὶ σκοπεῖν. Ti μέν• ὡς Ti τὴν TE; Tj τὴν τὴν μὰ τὴν 4TE w(ri) τὸν φορέσειν au e; TO σφάλματα de ἀμείπειν cp. ἀφαίρεσιν T; σκοπεῖν Tvώο; οὐκ ὀρθῶς δὲ δ. ἔχειν τὴν Ti κόσμῳ


instances where Ti is in agreement with one (or both) of the other two transmitted texts. One can think of a number of plausible explanations for this phenomenon,21 and we cannot establish that Ti is an improved version of at least one of the transmitted texts a priori. It is likely, though, that in certain cases Ti, which at one point was the preferred reading in antiquity, constitutes a further step in the ’Stissagio’ process, improvement of the transmitted texts.22 Often preference given to a certain line of transmission survives a change of hand in the transmission, e.g., when Scholia (scholion) come from different recensions.23 The emergence of a further step in the transmission after retouching of both transmitted texts is rarer, but it does occur, and it is likely that such examples will be obvious to anyone consulted for a revision.24

One can think of a number of plausible explanations for this phenomenon,21 and we cannot establish that Ti is an improved version of at least one of the transmitted texts a priori. It is likely, though, that in certain cases Ti, which at one point was the preferred reading in antiquity, constitutes a further step in the ’Stissagio’ process, improvement of the transmitted texts.22 Often preference given to a certain line of transmission survives a change of hand in the transmission, e.g., when Scholia (scholion) come from different recensions.23 The emergence of a further step in the transmission after retouching of both transmitted texts is rarer, but it does occur, and it is likely that such examples will be obvious to anyone consulted for a revision.24


1 Introduction


Plan of the book


The text printed in this volume is (almost) always, apart from very few exceptions, the new text set at the head of this introduction: Mark Paris 70 London, BM 47563. It is supplemented by the (also new) text of Parthenius Epigram 6, which is measured and transcribed by Adams 2004: 171. The readings of Diogenes Laertius and Aulus Gellius, labeled throughout as T and Tv, are (largely) presenting alternatives to those of Paris, T(e) and κκκ (cf. pauca supplementa and aHe s.v. κκκ), the choice here being informed by a “best guess” approach. Contrary to the vast majority of the new material contained in this volume, their readings are obviously not in need of reconstruction.

One can think of a number of plausible explanations for this phenomenon,21 and we cannot establish that Ti is an improved version of at least one of the transmitted texts a priori. It is likely, though, that in certain cases Ti, which at one point was the preferred reading in antiquity, constitutes a further step in the ’Stissagio’ process, improvement of the transmitted texts.22 Often preference given to a certain line of transmission survives a change of hand in the transmission, e.g., when Scholia (scholion) come from different recensions.23 The emergence of a further step in the transmission after retouching of both transmitted texts is rarer, but it does occur, and it is likely that such examples will be obvious to anyone consulted for a revision.24

Plan of the book


The text printed in this volume is (almost) always, apart from very few exceptions, the new text set at the head of this introduction: Mark Paris 70 London, BM 47563. Contrary to the vast majority of the new material contained in this volume, their readings are obviously not in need of reconstruction.

It is likely, though, that in certain cases Ti, which at one point was the preferred reading in antiquity, constitutes a further step in the ’Stissagio’ process, improvement of the transmitted texts.22 Often preference given to a certain line of transmission survives a change of hand in the transmission, e.g., when Scholia (scholion) come from different recensions.23 The emergence of a further step in the transmission after retouching of both transmitted texts is rarer, but it does occur, and it is likely that such examples will be obvious to anyone consulted for a revision.24


1 Introduction


Plan of the book


The text printed in this volume is (almost) always, apart from very few exceptions, the new text set at the head of this introduction: Mark Paris 70 London, BM 47563. It is supplemented by the (also new) text of Parthenius Epigram 6, which is measured and transcribed by Adams 2004: 171. The readings of Diogenes Laertius and Aulus Gellius, labeled throughout as T and Tv, are (largely) presenting alternatives to those of Paris, T(e) and κκκ (cf. pauca supplementa and aHe s.v. κκκ), the choice here being informed by a “best guess” approach. Contrary to the vast majority of the new material contained in this volume, their readings are obviously not in need of reconstruction.

It has been suggested (Berthelot {1907, 105-106} and Powell {2012}) that this passage influenced the "Alexander Romance" in the above-mentioned way:
Stesichoros’s description of Perseus describes, in a very accurate poetic fashion (for the time), the crossing of the Danube by Alexander the Great. groundtruth.region: κἀγὼ γὰρ, ὃς τὰ δείν’ ἐκαρτέρουν τότε, βαφῇ σίδηρος ὣς, ἐθηλύνθην στόμα πρὸς τῆςδε τῆς γυναικός· οἰκτείρω δέ νιν χήραν παρ’ ἐχθροῖς, παῖδά τ’ ὀρφανὸν ἀλλ’ εἶμι πρός τε λουτρὰ καὶ παρακτίους λειμῶνας, ὡς ἂν λύμαθ’ ἁγνίσας ἐμὰ μῆνιν βαρεῖαν ἐξαλεύσωμαι θεᾶς· μολών τε, χῶρον ἔνθ’ ἂν ἀστιβῆ κίχω, κρύψω τόδ’ ἔγχος τοὐμὸν, ἔχθιστον βελῶν, γαίας ὀρύξας ἔνθα μή τις ὄψεται. ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ νὺξ Ἅιδης τε σωζόντων κάτω. ἐγὼ γὰρ ἐξ οὖ χειρὶ τοῦτ’ ἐδεξάμην παρ’ Ἕκτορος δώρημα δυςμενεστάτου, οὔπώ τι κεδνὸν ἔσχον Ἀργείων πάρα. ἀλλ’ ἔστ’ ἀληθὴς ἡ βροτῶν παροιμία, ἐχθρῶν ἄδωρα δῶρα κοὐκ ὀνήσιμα. τοιγὰρ τὸ λοιπὸν εἰσόμεσθα μὲν θεοῖς εἴκειν, μαθησόμεσθα δ’ Ἀτρείδας σέβειν. ἄρχοντές εἰσιν, ὥςθ’ ὑπεικτέον· τί μή ; καὶ γὰρ τὰ δεινὰ καὶ τὰ καρτερώτατα τιμαῖς ὑπείκει· τοῦτο μὲν νιφοστιβεῖς χειμῶνες ἐκχωροῦσιν εὐκάρπῳ θέρει· ἐξίσταται δὲ νυκτὸς αἰανῆς κύκλος τῇ λευκοπώλῳ φέγγος ἡμέρᾳ φλέγειν. δεινῶν τ’ ἄημα πνευμάτων ἐκοίμισε στένοντα πόντον· ἐν δ’ ὁ παγκρατὴς ὕπνος λύει πεδήσας οὐδ’ ἀεὶ λαβὼν ἔχει. ἡμεῖς δὲ πῶς οὐ γνωσόμεσθα σωφρονεῖν ; ἐγὼ δ’, ἐπίσταμαι γὰρ ἀρτίως ὅτι ὅ τ’ ἐχθρὸς ἡμῖν ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος, ὡς καὶ φιλήσων αὖθις· ἔς τε τὸν φίλον τοσαῦθ’ ὑπουργῶν ὠφελεῖν βουλήσομαι,

It is likely, though, that in certain cases Ti, which at one point was the preferred reading in antiquity, constitutes a further step in the ’Stissagio’ process, improvement of the transmitted texts.22 Often preference given to a certain line of transmission survives a change of hand in the transmission, e.g., when Scholia (scholion) come from different recensions.23 The emergence of a further step in the transmission after retouching of both transmitted texts is rarer, but it does occur, and it is likely that such examples will be obvious to anyone consulted for a revision.24


1 Introduction


Plan of the book


The text printed in this volume is (almost) always, apart from very few exceptions, the new text set at the head of this introduction: Mark Paris 70 London, BM 47563. It is supplemented by the (also new) text of Parthenius Epigram 6, which is measured and transcribed by Adams 2004: 171. Contrary to the vast majority of the new material contained in this volume, their readings are obviously not in need of reconstruction.

This excerpt comes from a 20-printed-page book. OCR software works very well on printed texts and manages to correctly recognize characters and in general OCR phonetic conversion is also correct. The problem is with typographers who add symbols between words i.e. accent marks over original letters, or cross out symbols instead of replacing a symbol with an apostrophe. Other common error is doubling apostrophes that mark caesuras. In addition you can spot cases of split words divided in wrong places, and missing hyphens, accents, etc.

prediction.line:
δοκεῖν πεσεῖν ἂν κἂν ἀπὸ μικροῦ κακοῦ.

Here in "Dindorf", this passage is wrongfully ascribed to Demetrius of Phaleron (Dindorf, "Demetrius Capito (sic): Fragmenta eruditorum antiquissimi 1882, p. 71"

Another common mistake the OCR makes in this text is to render \xi\ as X at the beginning of a word.
